5CB5F06C0BF64864994D3CC2D2A648DD.description:
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about how changes in environmental
conditions may result in (1) increases in the number of individuals of some species, (2) the
emergence of new species over time, and (3) the extinction of other species.

24F9CE0A9F9E4709B517D690366F6C93.description:
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how natural selection leads to adaptation in
populations.

E996454B419D406D922993A6180F95FB.description:
Analyze and interpret data that natural selection is influenced by (1) the potential for a species
to increase in number, (2) the heritable genetic variation of individuals in a species due to
mutation and sexual reproduction, (3) competition for limited resources, and (4) the
proliferation of those organisms that are better able to survive and reproduce in the environment.

E41CC92F11FF4BBEAD49EAD5A339C213.description:
Apply concepts of statistics (i.e. probability) to support explanations that organisms in a
population with an advantageous heritable trait tend to increase in proportion to organisms
lacking this trait.

620E759561414D66842E593501EFD3EF.description:
Analyze and interpret scientific data that common ancestry and biological evolution are
supported by multiple lines of empirical evidence (e.g. DNA sequences, amino acid sequences,
anatomical structures, the fossil record, biogeography, or order of appearance of structures
during embryological development).

5E92235251EB4E71BF7AB68AF9490FD9.description:
Construct an explanation based on evidence that genetic variations may result from (a) new
genetic combinations via the processes of crossing over and random segregation of
chromosomes during meiosis, (b) mutations that occur during replication, and/or (c) mutations
caused by environmental factors. Evidence should include that mutations that occur in gametes
can be passed to offspring.

21369EE5FEB84D159013816447AD5C91.description:
Ask questions to clarify that variation of traits arises from differences in genes (alleles) and how
cells regulate gene expression.

AD8DEAABD3BC4C29850995EBCC089BBA.description:
Engage in an argument from evidence that the process of meiosis exists to create genetic
variation in a population from the creation of new combinations of genetic material in each of
the haploid gametes.

144885B17E004B86A7C58D4A9BF73DA5.description:
Engage in an argument from evidence that the process of cellular division (mitosis) creates
diploid daughter cells that are genetically identical to the diploid parent cells.

2D95725864B240E990FC9E055D144BCC.description: Heredity: Inheritance and Variation of Traits

1370EF2B3C664717A946A79D7A4E6443.description:
Analyze data about the role of group behavior on individual and species’ chances to survive and
reproduce.

027BD540D4954AFF9D88394493F69947.description:
Design, evaluate, and refine a solution for reducing the impacts of human activities on the
environment and biodiversity.

FC71ECBB1DEF4F50A52B37EB4E6E4EC7.description: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information based on evidence to describe how the impact of varying levels of disturbance is related to the resilience of an ecosystem.

984D6C6EC5B74CDC9C9D1DCB5C25C3C9.description:
Create, or use, a mathematical model to describe the transfer of energy from one trophic level
to another. Explain how the inefficiency of energy transfer between trophic levels affects the
relative number of organisms that can be supported at each trophic level and necessitates a
constant input of energy from sunlight and inorganic compounds from the environment.

67168B15188547DC822E499F1210983E.description:
Use mathematical and/or computational representations to support explanations of factors that
affect carrying capacity of ecosystems at different scales.

F99269384A224818ABD7EC0778DE16EA.description:
Construct an explanation from evidence to explain how the integrated functions of the brain in
complex animals results in successful interpretation of input and generation of behaviors in
response to those inputs.

62B91117A8BF48A5B21CDE711B03507E.description:
Create, or use, a model to describe how cellular respiration transforms stored chemical energy
of food resulting in a net transfer of energy. Compare aerobic respiration to alternative
processes of glucose metabolism.

96A5EABD733F4AC3B62DB260E3942EBC.description:
Construct an explanation based on evidence that matter taken into an organism can be broken
down and recombined to make macromolecules necessary for life functions.

38F0E712A6764EBAACCAB5CD263C9445.description:
Create, or use, a model to describe how the process of photosynthesis converts light energy into
the stored chemical energy of bonds created by converting CO2 and H2O into sugar and other
organic molecules.

A6E81D280E474407832022F9C210EE62.description:
Use a model to describe how differentiation in a multicellular organism creates specialized cells
that perform diverse functions to work together to meet the needs of the entire organism,
including human development

35DEA5CA549142AEB9B888BF5FDEC00C.description:
Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that feedback mechanisms maintain
homeostasis.

4CA58C6DEFBF45D58E542FD4996306EF.description:
Construct an explanation based on evidence that the essential functions of life are primarily
carried out through the work of proteins that are coded for by genes in DNA, as described by the
Central Dogma (i.e., transcription, translation).

47509DF9B96D49C59B63DAB314F48965.description: From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes
